results.title: Great Barrier Reef (Greek)
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Great Barrier Reef of Queensland is one of the great reservoirs of marine and animal life. This documentary shows in detail, the birds, fish and mammals of the area and the work being done by scientists in studying them. A long sequence deals with the life cycle of the turtle, another with the microscopic creatures of the sea.

results.title: Great Australian disasters of the 20th century
results.creator_credit: Bruce Leonard and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: As unpredictable as ultimate destiny, disasters can strike at any time. They are major misfortunes, occurrences that cause great suffering or privation, and are usually accompanied by the sudden and unexpected loss of human life. Throughout the 20th century, Australian cameramen and documentary filmmakers have recorded on film the great disasters that have befallen this nation, often at the very real risk of personal injury. This video looks at train collisions, aviation crashes, bridge collapses, mine explosions, fires, floods, droughts, earthquakes and cyclones.

results.title: Grass displaces scabweed in central Otago
results.brief_description: Land ruined by rabbits and overgrazing is restored (after the defeat of the rabbit pest) by sown tufted grass. Main purpose of the film is to show types of grasses which have replaced scab weed.

results.title: Grass and clover seed production
results.brief_description: Describes how new strains of clover and grasses are evolved at the Welsh Plant Breeding Station by crossing elected strains, careful pollination and then breeding from hybrid progeny. The film then shows recommended practices for farmers in sowing , fertilising, cutting and threshing clover and rye grass for seed production. Grasses dealt with include red and wild white clover, perennial rye grass and cocksfoot. The necessity for use of certified seed in seed production is stressed.

results.title: Grange Hill by Phil Redmond
results.brief_description: Adapted from the first series of the popular children’s program screened on the BBC in the 1980’s. For Form 1 Alpha at Grange Hill, their first year at high school will be an exciting and challenging one but with the help of the staff at Grange Hill, they’ll probably make it. Trisha tries to exercise her creativity by brightening up the school uniform, Benny has to put in some hard work to qualify for the football team, Judy is threatened by the school bullies and Tucker has too many encounters to mention. Starring Michael Percival, Denys Hawthorne, Dorothea Phillips and Carole Nimmons.

results.title: Grandfathers and revolutions
results.creator_credit: Peter Hegedus, Australian Film Commission, Griffith University and Pacific Film and Television Commission.
results.brief_description: A personal and compelling journey into the lives of the Hegedus family whose patriarch was the Prime Minister of Hungary during the bloody Hungarian Revolution of 1956. The documentary’s creator and Hegedus’s grandson, Peter, travels back to Hungary to determine whether his grandfather is really the man responsible for the deaths of those killed in the revolution. The documentary acts as Peter’s personal diary with entries including interviews with his grandfather and Hungarians who blame Hegedus for the deaths of relatives and friends during the revolution. (Awards: Winner of five international awards including Crystal Heart Award, Grand Prix Award - 22e Festival International du Film Independent and Grand Prix for Best Television Documentary - 14th Parnu International Documentary Festival).

results.title: Grand Manan
results.brief_description: The people of Grand Manan, New Brunswick, derive their living from the abundance of fish—cod, haddock, herring, hake and sardines—which inhabit the Bay of Fundy.

results.title: Grampa's sci-fi hits
results.creator_credit: Peter Zasuly, Bertram Siegelson and Amvest Video
results.brief_description: Grampa Munster, one of the most popular stars from the 60’s television series “The Munsters”, presents a selection of movie trailers from famous and less prominent science fictions films. Trailers featured include: Flash Gordon (1936), Flash Gordon’s trip to Mars (1938), Flash Gordon (1980), Godzilla (1956), Destroy all monsters (1968), King Kong (1933), Alien (1978), Barbarella (1968), Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Dr. Goldfoot and his girl bombs (1966), Buck Rogers (1978), Omega man (1971), Fahrenheit 451 (1966), The Blob (1958), 30 ft. bride of Candy Rock (1959), Village of the giants (1965), The Amazing colossal man (1957), Godzilla vs. Megalon (1976), Ghidra, the three headed monster (1964), Varan the unbelievable (1962), Reptilicus (1961), Atragon (1963), Creation of the humanoids (1962), Battle of the worlds (1961), Earth vs. the flying saucers (1956), This Island Earth (1954), The Day the Earth stood still (1951), and Lost world (1960).

results.title: Grampa's monster movies
results.creator_credit: Peter Zasuly, Bertram Siegelson and Amvest Video
results.brief_description: Grampa Munster leads the viewer through an exploration of classic monster movie trailers. Trailers featured include: House of Frankenstein (1944), House of Dracula (1945), Son of Dracula (1943), Dracula’s daughter (1936), Dracula (1931), The Invisible man returns (1940), The Invisible woman (1940), Invisible agent (1942), The Invisible ray (1936), Frankenstein (1931), Frankenstein meets the Wolf Man (1943), Bride of Frankenstein (1935), The ghost of Frankenstein (1942), Abbott and Costello meet Frankenstein (1948), Phantom of the opera (1943), The Climax (19??), The Werewolf of London (1935), The Mystery of Marie Roget (1942), Murders in the Rue Morgue (1932), Flesh and fantasy (1943), The Wolfman (1941), The Mummy (1932), The Mummy’s hand (1940), The Mummy’s curse (1944), The Black cat (1934), The Cat creeps (1946), Black Friday (1940), and Horror island (1941).
